terms.definition: A type of stick used in hockey for playing the ball or puck on the back side of the stick.
A technique where the batter lightly taps the ball instead of swinging at it to make contact.
A high-impact move where a player jumps and scores by putting the ball directly through the hoop with one or both hands.
A soft shot intended to land just over the net and make it difficult for the opponent to reach.
An obstacle that athletes must jump over during a race.
The player positioned in the goal area who is responsible for preventing the ball or puck from entering the net.
A serve that is so well-placed that the opponent cannot return it.
A term for a rower who has a strong finish but may not be as consistent throughout the race.
A method of scoring by shooting the ball close to the basket, typically after a quick dribble or move.
A verbal taunt or trash talk used to distract or intimidate opponents.
When a player moves quickly past defenders to get a clear chance at scoring, often with minimal opposition.
In tennis, hitting the ball before it bounces; in volleyball, hitting the ball in the air before it hits the ground.
A method of restarting play where players from each team bind together and push against each other to compete for the ball.
The act of throwing the ball towards the batter, or the area where the game is played.
A method of scoring by dropping the ball and kicking it through the goalposts as it touches the ground.
In tennis, a series of games won by a player; in volleyball, a tactical move where a player positions the ball for a teammate to spike.
The act of intercepting or challenging an opponent to gain possession of the ball.
A kick awarded to a team after a foul by the opposing team, taken from the spot where the foul occurred.
A routine where cheerleaders perform acrobatic moves, such as lifting or throwing a teammate into the air.
A powerful shot where the player jumps and thrusts the ball through the hoop with one or both hands.
A stroke where the player hits the ball with the front side of the racket.
A tool used to propel a boat through water, consisting of a long handle with a blade at each end.
The action of passing the ball from the center to the quarterback to start a play.
A defensive move where a player uses their body or stick to block an opponent’s movement or take the puck away.
A swimming style where the swimmer lies on their back and uses an alternating arm and leg motion.
A dive where the diver performs a somersault while moving forward.
A U-shaped ramp used for performing tricks and aerial maneuvers.
A quick, straight punch with the lead hand, often used to set up more powerful punches.
A series of shots played to recover from a difficult position, often to save par.
A driving technique where the driver intentionally oversteers, causing the car to slide sideways through a turn.
A move where a wrestler drops to their knees to land on their opponent, often used in finishing moves.
A maneuver where a player moves from a defensive to an offensive position by swimming up.
A term used to describe a smooth and coordinated rowing stroke.
A deceptive move used to trick an opponent into reacting, creating an opening for a real attack.
A defensive move where a player flattens their hands and arms to make a dig.
A tactic where a player uses their body to push an opponent off the puck or ball.
A technique used to maintain speed and momentum while minimizing resistance on the ice.
Protective gear worn on the lower legs to prevent injury from impacts.
A technique used to curve the ball around a wall of defenders during a free kick.
A brief pause or change in rhythm during a sprint, often used strategically in races.
A defensive strategy where players exchange their defensive assignments during a screen.
A small, repetitive motion made with the club before a swing to establish rhythm and relax the hands.
A deceptive move used to trick an opponent and gain an advantage, such as faking a shot or pass.
A board used for standing and paddling on water, typically on calm lakes or seas.
A situation where one team has a numerical advantage due to an opponent’s penalty.
A defensive move followed by an offensive attack, used to exploit an opponent’s openings.
A system used to determine whether the ball has fully crossed the goal line, ensuring accurate goal decisions.
A technique where the rider or skier uses the edge of their board or skis to make clean, sharp turns.
A move used to bring an opponent from a standing position to the ground.
The sound made when a diver enters the water, often used to describe an imperfect dive with excessive splash.
A stroke where the player hits the ball with the back of the racket facing them.
The center of the target, worth the highest score if hit.
A term for scoring two strokes over par on a hole.
A strength sport focusing on three main lifts: squat, bench press, and deadlift.
A technique where a lifter performs a set of an exercise to failure, then immediately reduces the weight and continues the set.
A statistical achievement where a player records double digits in three statistical categories (e.g., points, rebounds, assists) in one game.
Scoring three goals in a single game by one player.
A penalty shot awarded to a player from the free-throw line, worth one point.
The number of strokes an expert golfer is expected to take to complete a hole or course.
Additional time added to a game if it ends in a tie, to determine the winner.
A game in which a pitcher prevents the opposing team from getting any hits.
Winning all four major tournaments in a single year: the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and the US Open.
A victory achieved when the opponent is rendered unconscious or unable to continue fighting.
A race where team members pass a baton to each other in a set sequence.
A direct shot taken from a spot 12 yards from the goal, awarded after a foul within the penalty area.
A shot or kick made from the field to score points, typically worth two or three points in basketball or three points in football.
A forceful hit of the ball from above the net, aimed to score a point.
A defensive play where two offensive players are put out in one continuous action.
A term for a rower who has a strong finish but may not be as consistent throughout the race.
The area at each end of the field where a touchdown is scored.
A sudden, rapid move by a cyclist to escape the pack and gain a lead.
A position where the opponent’s king is in check and cannot escape, ending the game.
A container used for organizing fishing gear.
When a player serves twice in a row incorrectly, resulting in the loss of the point.
A punch delivered with a bent arm, targeting the side of the opponent’s head or body.
A term for the upright targets that players aim to knock down with the bowling ball.
The act of jumping or falling into water, typically from a platform or springboard, with an emphasis on style and precision.
A U-shaped ramp used for performing tricks and aerial maneuvers.
A quick, straight punch with the lead hand, often used to set up more powerful punches.
A maneuver where a player moves from a defensive to an offensive position by swimming up.
A term used to describe a smooth and coordinated rowing stroke.
A deceptive move used to trick an opponent into reacting, creating an opening for a real attack.
A defensive move where a player flattens their hands and arms to make a dig.
A tactic where a player uses their body to push an opponent off the puck or ball.
A technique used to maintain speed and momentum while minimizing resistance on the ice.
Protective gear worn on the lower legs to prevent injury from impacts.

A brief pause or change in rhythm during a sprint, often used strategically in races.
A defensive strategy where players exchange their defensive assignments during a screen.

A deceptive move used to trick an opponent and gain an advantage, such as faking a shot or pass.

A situation where one team has a numerical advantage due to an opponent’s penalty.
A defensive move followed by an offensive attack, used to exploit an opponent’s openings.
A system used to determine whether the ball has fully crossed the goal line, ensuring accurate goal decisions.
A technique where the rider or skier uses the edge of their board or skis to make clean, sharp turns.
A move used to bring an opponent from a standing position to the ground.
The sound made when a diver enters the water, often used to describe an imperfect dive with excessive splash.
A stroke where the player hits the ball with the back of the racket facing them.
The center of the target, worth the highest score if hit.
A term for scoring two strokes over par on a hole.

A technique where a lifter performs a set of an exercise to failure, then immediately reduces the weight and continues the set.
